docs.title: TRIX AR/VR Interactive System
docs.text: Welcome to the official website for the TRIX AR/VR project.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: This site serves as the central hub for documenting our journey in developing a cutting-edge hybrid marker-based AR pizza visualization system. Here, we will share our learnings, publish progress updates, and post insightful blogs as we decode the process of building an immersive AR/VR experience.

docs.title: What to Expect
docs.text:
• Project Documentation: Detailed technical guides, architecture overviews, and implementation notes.
  • Learning Resources: Insights gained, best practices, and lessons learned throughout the development process.
  • Progress Updates: Regular updates on milestones, features, and improvements.
  • Blogs: In-depth articles exploring challenges, solutions, and narratives from our development journey.
  • Scalability & Adoption: Strategies and narratives on scaling the system for adoption by pizza chains worldwide.

docs.title: Project Overview
docs.text:
Our project focuses on building a hybrid AR system leveraging:

  • QR code-based content retrieval
  • SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping) for surface detection
  • 3D object rendering for interactive pizza visualization

docs.title: Our Mission
docs.text:
We aim to create an engaging, scalable AR solution that can transform the way pizza chains interact with their customers globally. Along the way, we will document challenges, share our solutions, and provide a transparent narrative of our progress.

Stay tuned as we explore, innovate, and bring the future of AR/VR to the world of pizza!

docs.title: 🍕 Introduction
docs.text:
• Project Overview: The Marker-Based Augmented Reality (AR) Interactive Menu System enhances the in-restaurant dining experience, initially focusing on pizza chains.

  • Current Challenges:

    • Traditional menus rely on static images and text.
    • Customers face uncertainty about:
      • Portion sizes
      • Ingredient composition
      • Allergen presence
      • Nutritional value
    • Pizza menus often involve many variations and customizations, making choices harder.

  • Solution Highlights:

    • Introduces an immersive, lightweight AR approach.
    • Integrates with existing printed menus using marker-based tracking.
    • Transforms physical menus into interactive visualization platforms.
    • No need to replace current menu formats.

  • Scalability:

    • While starting with pizza chains, the system is designed to expand.
    • Can support other food categories (e.g., burgers, desserts, beverages).
    • Adaptable for diverse restaurant formats.

  • Key Benefits:

    • Improves customer decision-making at the point of ordering.
    • Offers interactive visualization for better engagement.
    • Supports dietary and customization needs.

docs.title: 🎯 SMART Objectives
docs.text:
1. Specific: Develop a marker-based AR menu system that overlays interactive 3D pizza models and ingredient information onto printed menus in participating pizza restaurants.

  2. Measurable: Achieve at least a 30% increase in customer engagement with menu items (measured by interaction rates within the AR app) within the first three months of deployment.

  3. Achievable: Complete the MVP (Minimum Viable Product) for pizza menus, including allergen and nutritional information display, within four months of project initiation.

  4. Relevant: Address customer uncertainty regarding portion sizes, ingredients, allergens, and nutrition by providing real-time, visual, and interactive menu data.

  5. Time-bound: Expand AR menu support to at least one additional food categories (e.g., burgers and desserts) and onboard three new restaurant partners within six months of initial launch.

docs.title: From Idea to Structure: Understanding What We Actually Built
docs.text: Author: Suhani Garg Tags: AR, VR

docs.title: Background Context
docs.text:
When we first proposed building an augmented reality–based menu system, the idea felt exciting and practical. The core concept was simple: scan a menu, display a 3D pizza in AR, and enhance the ordering experience. It seemed modern, interactive, and relevant to real-world use.

However, during our initial presentation, we realized that having a good idea is not the same as having a well-defined system. While the motivation behind the project was understood, several important structural questions were raised. These questions helped us recognize that we had explained what we wanted to build, but not clearly enough how it would function.

docs.title: Discussion and Key Questions Raised
docs.text:
During the discussion, one of the main concerns was about marker usage.

It was unclear whether:

  • A single marker would represent the entire menu
  • Multiple markers would be used for different items

This created ambiguity about how the system would scale and function in practice.

Another important question was:

“After scanning the marker, what exactly opens?”

We had not clearly defined:

  • Whether a new scene would load
  • How navigation between items would work
  • Whether rescanning would be required for each item

These questions revealed that our explanation lacked system-level clarity.

docs.title: Realizations from the Feedback
docs.text:
The biggest realization from Day 1 was that a project must be explained as a complete interaction flow, not just a list of features.

We understood that evaluators are assessing:

  • Clarity of system behavior
  • Correct identification of AR type
  • Logical scene structure
  • Realistic scope and implementation

Without defining marker behavior and scene persistence, the project risked appearing like a basic “scan-and-show” AR demo, even if additional features were planned.

docs.title: Structural Decisions Taken
docs.text:
Based on the feedback, we refined the structure of the project before moving forward.

The following decisions were made:

  • The system will use a single marker (menu card or QR image).
  • Scanning the marker will open one persistent AR scene.
  • All interactions will occur within that same scene.
  • Navigation between pizzas will happen using left and right arrows.
  • Ingredient details and nutrition toggles will function inside the same AR environment.

By defining this clearly, the project shifted from a conceptual AR idea to a structured interactive system.

docs.title: Key Learning from Day 1
docs.text:
Day 1 taught us that clarity is more important than complexity. Even a technically simple AR system can be strong if the interaction flow is clearly defined and logically structured.

The most important takeaway was:

Before building features, define the structure.

This reflection helped us move from idea-stage thinking to system-level planning.

docs.title: 🍕 Interactive Marker-Based AR Pizza Menu System
docs.text: Author: Srishti Garg Date: February 9, 2026

docs.title: 📌 Project Overview
docs.text:
The Interactive Marker-Based AR Pizza Menu System is an augmented reality application designed to enhance traditional restaurant menus using immersive 3D visualization.

Instead of relying on text descriptions and small images, this system allows users to:

  • Scan a printed menu
  • View realistic 3D pizza models
  • Interact with ingredients
  • Check nutrition information
  • Compare portion sizes visually

The goal is simple: Move from reading about food to experiencing food visually before ordering.

docs.title: 🎯 Motivation
docs.text:
Imagine walking into a café you’ve never visited before.

You look at the menu and see names like: Italian Supreme, BBQ Chicken, Veg Delight.

But you still don’t know:

  • What exactly is inside?
  • How big is medium?
  • Is it spicy?

You ask the waiter. They explain. You ask again. They gesture with their hands.

This repeated back-and-forth slows ordering and still doesn’t provide a clear visual understanding.

Our AR system eliminates this confusion.

docs.title: 🔹 Marker-Based AR Model
docs.text:
This project uses marker-based augmented reality.

Component Responsibility Printed Menu Acts as AR Marker Camera Feed Detects marker Unity Engine Renders 3D Pizza UI Controls Handles interaction

The pizza model is anchored directly to the detected marker, creating a stable AR environment.

docs.title: Step 1 — Marker Detection
docs.text: The smartphone camera detects the printed menu marker.

docs.title: Step 2 — Scene Initialization
docs.text: A single AR scene is created and anchored.

docs.title: Step 3 — 3D Pizza Rendering
docs.text: A default pizza model appears.

docs.title: Step 4 — Interaction
docs.text: Users can: - Navigate between pizzas - Change portion size - Tap toppings to view ingredient details - Toggle nutrition information

docs.title: ➤ Arrow-Based Navigation
docs.text: Switch between 5–8 predefined pizza varieties without rescanning.

docs.title: ➤ Portion Size Visualization
docs.text: The 3D model scales dynamically to represent Small, Medium, or Large.

docs.title: ➤ Ingredient-Level Interaction
docs.text: Each topping is interactive. Selecting it displays its name and description.

docs.title: ➤ Nutrition Toggle
docs.text: Users can view calorie details and basic health-related information.

docs.title: 📏 Project Scope
docs.text: The system is intentionally limited to pizza only.

docs.title: Included:
docs.text:
• 5–8 pizza varieties
  • Static 3D models
  • Ingredient highlighting
  • Nutrition information
  • Single-marker architecture

docs.title: Not Included:
docs.text:
• Online ordering
  • Payment integration
  • AI recommendations
  • Real-time customization
  • Cloud backend

This focused scope ensures clarity, stability, and feasibility within an academic environment.

docs.title: 🛠 Technology Stack
docs.text:
The system is developed using:

  • Unity 3D
  • AR Foundation
  • Vuforia SDK
  • Marker-Based AR
  • 3D Pizza Models
  • Android Smartphone Deployment

The application is currently implemented on Android for ease of testing and deployment but can be extended to iOS.

docs.title: 🧠 Technical Components Used
docs.text:
• Computer Vision
  • Feature Detection Algorithms
  • Marker Tracking
  • Pose Estimation
  • 3D Rendering
  • UI Integration in AR Space

docs.title: 🚀 Expected Outcome
docs.text:
This project demonstrates how augmented reality can transform a static menu into an interactive decision-making tool.

It enhances:

  • User confidence
  • Ordering speed
  • Visual clarity
  • Informational transparency

Rather than being a novelty feature, the AR system functions as a meaningful interface that improves everyday experiences like restaurant ordering.

🔄 Transition to Iteration Phase

While this blog focused on explaining the concept and architecture of the AR Pizza Menu System, the next stage involves refining interaction flow, scene persistence, and implementation stability. The upcoming development blog will document how the system evolves from conceptual design into a structured, stable AR experience.

docs.title: Marker-Based AR Interactive Pizza Menu System
docs.text: Author: Aakarsh Dhingra Module Type: Core Rendering & Optimization Layer System Type: Marker-Based Augmented Reality

docs.title: 1. Module Overview
docs.text:
The 3D Asset Management Module powers the AR pizza menu by:

  • Importing and managing 3D pizza models
  • Optimizing models for mobile AR rendering
  • Structuring ingredient-level interaction
  • Managing runtime model switching
  • Handling nutrition and metadata binding

Key Benefits:

  • High frame rates
  • Low memory usage
  • Smooth model switching
  • Seamless AR interaction

docs.title: 2. Asset Architecture Structure
docs.text:
The asset system uses a clear, modular hierarchy:

Assets/
├── Models/
│   ├── Margherita.fbx
│   ├── Farmhouse.fbx
│   └── Pepperoni.fbx
├── Textures/
│   ├── Cheese_Base.png
│   ├── Pepperoni_Texture.png
│   └── Veggies_Texture.png
├── Prefabs/
│   ├── Margherita_Prefab
│   ├── Farmhouse_Prefab
│   └── Pepperoni_Prefab
├── Scripts/
│   ├── PizzaManager.cs
│   ├── IngredientHandler.cs
│   └── NutritionToggle.cs
└── Data/
    └── PizzaData.json

Advantages:

  • Modular and scalable
  • Clear separation of concerns

docs.title: 3.1 Supported File Formats
docs.text:
• .fbx (Preferred)
  • .obj (Alternative)

docs.title: 3.2 Import Workflow
docs.text:
1. Design model in Blender or Maya
  2. Export as optimized low-poly .fbx
  3. Import into Unity
  4. Convert to Prefab
  5. Attach colliders
  6. Structure ingredient objects as children

docs.title: 4.1 Polygon Budget
docs.text:
• 5,000–20,000 triangles per pizza
  • Lightweight ingredient meshes
  • Avoid unnecessary subdivisions

docs.title: 4.2 Texture Optimization
docs.text:
• Resolution: 512x512 or 1024x1024
  • Compression: ASTC (Android), ETC2 fallback
  • Texture atlasing

docs.title: 4.3 Lighting Strategy
docs.text:
• Baked lighting
  • Mobile-optimized shaders
  • Real-time shadows disabled

docs.title: 4.4 Draw Call Reduction
docs.text:
• Static batching
  • Shared materials
  • Mesh combination where possible

docs.title: 5.1 Preloading Strategy
docs.text:
• All prefabs loaded at scene start
  • Kept inactive until needed
  • Activated dynamically to prevent runtime lag

docs.title: 5.2 Arrow-Based Switching Logic
docs.text:
currentIndex = (currentIndex + 1) % pizzaList.Count;
// Deactivate current model
// Update index
// Activate next model
// Reset transform relative to marker

docs.title: 6. Ingredient-Level Object Structuring
docs.text:
Prefab Hierarchy:

Pizza
├── Base
├── Cheese
├── Topping_Pepperoni
├── Topping_Mushroom
└── Topping_Olive

Each topping includes:

  • Mesh Renderer
  • Collider
  • Metadata reference ID

Enables:

  • Raycast detection
  • Independent interaction

docs.title: 7. Data Binding & Metadata System
docs.text: All pizza details are stored in JSON for flexibility.

docs.title: 7.1 Example Structure
docs.text:
{
  "name": "Margherita",
  "model": "Margherita_Prefab",
  "ingredients": [
    {
      "id": "cheese",
      "name": "Mozzarella",
      "allergen": "Dairy",
      "description": "High-quality Italian mozzarella"
    }
  ],
  "nutrition": {
    "calories": 250,
    "protein": "11g",
    "carbs": "30g",
    "dietType": "Vegetarian"
  }
}

docs.title: 7.2 Why Separate Data?
docs.text:
• Easier updates
  • No need to modify 3D models
  • Supports scalability

docs.title: 8.1 Raycasting Mechanism
docs.text:
When the user taps:

  1. Touch detected
  2. Raycast projected
  3. Collider hit detected
  4. Ingredient ID retrieved
  5. UI popup displayed

docs.title: 9. Performance Safeguards
docs.text:
To maintain stable FPS (30–60):

  • Minimized garbage collection
  • Object pooling if required
  • No heavy dynamic physics
  • Frame debugger testing

docs.title: 10. Scalability Design
docs.text:
The module supports:

  • Adding new pizza variants
  • Expanding the ingredient database
  • Backend integration
  • Future animation upgrades

docs.title: 11. Engineering Considerations
docs.text: Factor Solution Mobile memory limits Texture compression Frame drops Polygon cap Switching lag Preloading prefabs CPU load Avoid real-time shadows Scalability JSON-driven data

docs.title: 12. Module Flow Summary
docs.text:
Input:

  • Marker detection active
  • User arrow click
  • Ingredient tap

Processing:

  • Prefab activation/deactivation
  • Raycast detection
  • JSON metadata retrieval

Output:

  • 3D pizza rendered
  • Ingredient information popup
  • Nutrition overlay updated

docs.title: 🍕 High Level Design of Pizza Visualization System
docs.text: Author: Akarsh Date: February 13, 2026

docs.title: 📌 Project Overview
docs.text:
This project presents a Hybrid Augmented Reality (AR) system that combines:

  • QR Code-based Data Retrieval
  • SLAM-based Surface Detection
  • 3D Object Placement on Real-world Tables

Unlike traditional marker-based AR systems, this architecture separates:

  • QR Code → Data Trigger
  • SLAM → Real-world Surface Placement

This enables a more immersive and technically advanced AR experience.

docs.title: 🎯 System Capabilities
docs.text:
The system allows users to:

  1. Scan a QR code on a restaurant menu
  2. Load the complete pizza menu dynamically
  3. Select a specific pizza
  4. View a 3D pizza model rendered on the real table

docs.title: 🔹 Hybrid Model
docs.text:
Component Responsibility QR Code Data Retrieval SLAM Surface Detection User Selection 3D Rendering

⚠️ The pizza does NOT appear on the QR marker. The QR only triggers data loading.

docs.title: 1️⃣ Camera Frame Acquisition
docs.text:
The mobile camera continuously captures frames (30–60 FPS).

Preprocessing steps:

  • Grayscale conversion
  • Edge detection
  • Corner detection

docs.title: 2️⃣ Feature Point Extraction
docs.text:
AR SDKs used:

  • ARCore
  • ARKit
  • Vuforia
  • AR Foundation

docs.title: Algorithms Used Internally
docs.text:
• ORB (Oriented FAST and Rotated BRIEF)
  • FAST Corner Detection
  • SIFT / SURF (legacy)

QR codes are ideal due to:

  • High black-white contrast
  • Strong geometric structure

Each detected feature becomes a 2D coordinate in image space.

docs.title: 3️⃣ Feature Matching
docs.text:
• Live camera features
  • Stored QR reference features

Matched using descriptor comparison.

If sufficient matches are found → Marker detected successfully.

docs.title: 4️⃣ Pose Estimation
docs.text:
The system computes:

  • Rotation (R)
  • Translation (T)

Using:

  • Perspective-n-Point (PnP)
  • Homography Matrix

This determines QR position and orientation in 3D space.

docs.title: What is SLAM?
docs.text:
SLAM = Simultaneous Localization and Mapping

It performs:

  1. Environment mapping
  2. Device movement tracking

docs.title: Step 1 — Environmental Feature Tracking
docs.text:
Detected features:

  • Table edges
  • Wood patterns
  • Corners
  • Texture variations

docs.title: Step 2 — Motion Tracking
docs.text:
Combines:

  • Camera input
  • Gyroscope
  • Accelerometer

docs.title: Step 3 — Point Cloud Creation
docs.text: Tracked features form a sparse 3D point cloud.

docs.title: Step 4 — Plane Detection
docs.text:
Using RANSAC:

  • Coplanar points clustered
  • Surface model fitted

If enough horizontal points exist → Plane detected.

docs.title: Step 1 — QR Scan
docs.text:
• QR detected
  • JSON menu loaded
  • UI updates
  • No 3D object rendered

docs.title: Step 2 — SLAM Activation
docs.text:
• User moves phone
  • Table surface detected
  • Plane visualization appears

docs.title: Step 3 — Pizza Selection
docs.text:
• 3D prefab instantiated
  • Hit test performed
  • Object anchored to plane
  • Pizza appears

docs.title: 🎯 Hit Testing & Object Placement
docs.text:
When placing pizza:

  1. User taps screen (x, y)
  2. Ray cast from camera
  3. Ray intersects detected plane
  4. Intersection coordinate returned
  5. Object placed

docs.title: 📐 Ray Equation
docs.text:
P = O + tD

Where:

  • O = Camera origin
  • D = Direction vector
  • t = Scalar

docs.title: 📐 Plane Equation
docs.text:
Ax + By + Cz + D = 0

Solving ray-plane intersection gives world coordinate.

docs.title: Option A — Pure Marker-Based
docs.text:
• Pizza appears directly on QR
  • Simpler implementation
  • Lower computational load

docs.title: Option B — Hybrid (Recommended)
docs.text:
• QR = Data trigger only
  • SLAM = Real-world placement

docs.title: Advantages
docs.text:
• More immersive
  • Strong academic value
  • Better UX

docs.title: ⚠️ Engineering Note
docs.text:
If pizza is placed relative to table:

  • QR does NOT control object position
  • It only triggers data loading

Placement depends on:

  • SLAM
  • Plane detection
  • Hit testing

docs.title: 🧩 Technical Components Used
docs.text:
• Computer Vision
  • Feature Detection
  • Pose Estimation
  • SLAM
  • Plane Detection
  • Ray Casting
  • 3D Rendering

docs.title: 🚀 Conclusion
docs.text:
This Hybrid AR architecture separates:

Data Retrieval (QR) from Spatial Placement (SLAM)

Creating a scalable and immersive AR system suitable for:

  • Restaurant visualization
  • AR commerce
  • Educational AR
  • Advanced HCI research

docs.title: 🍕 Hybrid Ar system for Pizza Visualization
docs.text: Author: Akarsh Date: February 13, 2026

docs.title: Project Overview
docs.text:
The AR/VR Interactive Marker-Based AR Menu Browsing System is an augmented reality application designed to explore how physical restaurant menus can be enhanced through immersive, interactive digital content.

The project investigates the use of marker-based AR as a practical, accessible, and low-cost approach for visualizing food items in three dimensions while maintaining a clear link between the physical and digital environments.

The primary objective of the system is to move beyond static images traditionally used in menus and instead offer users an interactive, spatially anchored browsing experience.

By scanning a physical marker — such as a printed menu card or QR-style image — users gain access to a virtual menu where food items can be explored visually, contextually, and interactively.

The project emphasizes:

  • Usability
  • System stability
  • Meaningful interaction

This makes it suitable for real-world deployment as well as academic demonstration.

docs.title: System Motivation and Design Philosophy
docs.text:
Early iterations of the project revealed a common limitation in basic AR applications:

  • Frequent re-scanning
  • Fragmented scenes
  • Interactions focused more on novelty than usability

Based on evaluative feedback, the system was refined to adopt a more structured and intentional interaction model.

The revised design prioritizes three core principles:

docs.title: 1️⃣ Scene Persistence
docs.text: Once activated, the AR environment should remain stable and continuous.

docs.title: 2️⃣ Minimal Physical Effort
docs.text: Users should not be required to repeatedly scan markers.

docs.title: 3️⃣ Meaningful Interaction
docs.text:
Every interaction should serve a functional or informational purpose.

These principles directly informed the architectural decisions made in the refined system.

docs.title: Marker-Based Architecture and Scene Initialization
docs.text:
At the foundation of the system lies a single-marker architecture.

Instead of assigning individual markers to each menu item, the application intentionally uses one physical marker to represent the entire menu.

This marker acts as a stable spatial anchor, defining the coordinate system in which all virtual content is rendered.

When the marker is detected by the device camera:

  • The application initializes a single AR scene
  • The scene loads once
  • The interaction session continues without reinitialization

This design:

  • Minimizes tracking loss
  • Reduces user friction
  • Preserves immersion

Upon successful detection, a default 3D pizza model is rendered and anchored directly to the marker, establishing a clear connection between the physical menu and its digital counterpart.

docs.title: Persistent Scene Navigation and Model Management
docs.text:
A defining feature of the refined system is its persistent AR scene.

After the initial scan:

  • The user does not need to interact with the marker again
  • Navigation is handled entirely through on-screen UI controls

Pizza variations are explored using left and right arrow buttons.

Each button press dynamically replaces the currently displayed pizza model with another variant.

Importantly:

  • Position remains constant
  • Orientation remains constant
  • Scale remains constant

Only the model changes.

This ensures:

  • Spatial consistency
  • No disorientation
  • Effective runtime asset swapping
  • Proper AR state management

This demonstrates how interactive AR systems can dynamically update content without resetting spatial anchors.

docs.title: Ingredient-Level Interaction and Information Discovery
docs.text:
To extend the experience beyond simple visualization, the system incorporates ingredient-level interaction.

Individual toppings on the pizza model are clickable interactive elements.

When selected:

  • The topping name appears
  • A brief descriptive overlay is displayed

This transforms the AR menu into an exploratory interface and demonstrates object-level interaction within a marker-based AR scene.

docs.title: Nutritional Information and UI Integration
docs.text:
The system also includes a nutrition toggle feature.

Users can display or hide:

  • Calorie values
  • Dietary classification (e.g., vegetarian / non-vegetarian)

This information is accessed through a dedicated UI button.

The toggle-based design ensures:

  • The AR scene remains visually clean
  • Information is available on demand
  • Users control their level of detail

This reflects strong UI design principles within immersive environments.

docs.title: Project Outcome and Technical Significance
docs.text:
Through its refinements, the project evolves from a basic AR visualization into a structured interactive system.

The final implementation demonstrates:

  • A strong understanding of marker-based AR principles
  • Effective UI and AR scene integration
  • Practical state and content management
  • A user-centered immersive interaction model

The Interactive Marker-Based AR Menu Browsing System showcases how augmented reality can be applied in a practical, intuitive, and technically sound manner.

Rather than functioning as a visual gimmick, the system presents AR as a meaningful interface capable of enhancing everyday experiences such as menu browsing through thoughtful interaction design.

docs.title: 🍕 Iteration 2 — Structuring the AR Pizza Experience
docs.text: Author: Srishti Garg Date: February 15, 2026

docs.title: 📌 Continuing From the Previous Blog
docs.text:
In my last blog, I explained the overall concept of the Interactive Marker-Based AR Pizza Menu System — how scanning a printed menu displays a 3D pizza in augmented reality, allowing users to explore ingredients, nutrition, and portion sizes.

At that stage, the idea was clear.

But while working on the implementation, I realized something important:

Designing an AR experience is not just about rendering a 3D model. It’s about defining interaction flow, stability, and structure.

This blog documents what I am refining while actively building the system.

docs.title: 🧠 Rethinking the User Flow
docs.text:
While developing the Unity scene, I asked myself:

  • What exactly happens after scanning?
  • Does the scene reload every time?
  • Should users rescan to switch pizzas?
  • How do I prevent tracking loss?

These questions forced me to move from “feature thinking” to “system thinking.”

docs.title: 🔄 Defining Scene Persistence
docs.text:
One major refinement I am currently implementing is persistent scene behavior.

Earlier, I only focused on:

  • Detect marker
  • Show pizza

Now, I am structuring it as:

  • Detect marker
  • Initialize AR scene once
  • Keep scene active
  • Swap pizza models dynamically
  • Maintain same anchor position

This ensures:

  • No repeated scanning
  • No scene reload
  • Stable user experience

docs.title: 🏗 Refining the Interaction Model
docs.text:
Instead of loading separate scenes for each pizza, I am now using:

  • Runtime prefab swapping
  • Fixed anchor position
  • Constant scale reference
  • UI-driven interaction

This keeps:

  • Spatial consistency
  • Orientation stable
  • User experience smooth

It also makes the system technically cleaner.

docs.title: 🧩 Improving Ingredient Interaction
docs.text:
While testing the topping selection feature, I realized that simply displaying text was not enough.

Now I am refining:

  • Highlight shader effect on selected topping
  • Floating info panel near pizza
  • Clear UI hierarchy to avoid clutter

This transforms the system from “visual demo” into an interactive exploration tool.

docs.title: 📊 Nutrition Toggle Optimization
docs.text:
The nutrition panel previously appeared abruptly.

Now I am adjusting:

  • Smooth fade animation
  • Toggle state memory
  • Positioning logic to avoid overlapping with model

This improves usability and reduces visual overload.

docs.title: 🎯 Technical Refinement in Progress
docs.text:
Currently working on:

  • Improving marker detection stability in Vuforia
  • Testing lighting variation performance
  • Adjusting 3D model optimization
  • Reducing unnecessary object instantiation
  • Ensuring frame rate stability

This phase is less visible to users but critical for system robustness.

docs.title: 💡 Key Realization During Development
docs.text:
While building this second phase, I’ve realized:

AR projects fail not because of missing features — but because of unstable structure.

Even a simple marker-based system becomes strong when:

  • Scene logic is clear
  • Interaction flow is intentional
  • State management is controlled
  • UI supports immersion

This blog marks the transition from idea to engineering refinement.
